Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this research project is to develop a miniature source of energetic electrons, an electron gun, for producing high quality, high energy electron beams. High energy electron beams have found widespread use by biologists, chemists and physicists investigating ultra-fast science through x-ray and electron diffraction; physicians performing medical imaging and radiation therapy; scientists exploring high energy physics; and for cargo screening at ports of entry across the country. These electron beams are generated in particle accelerators which manipulate the energy, density and timing of charged particles. The first building block of a particle accelerator is the electron gun, where electrons are emitted into a vacuum and interact with intense electric fields to be accelerated. The performance of the electron gun is critical because it sets the fundamental limits on the ability to control electron beams.

This research aims to develop an ultra-compact, high-gradient electron gun operating in the Terahertz (THz) frequency range which demonstrates GeV/m accelerating gradients with unprecedented brightness and temporal control of the electron beam. An electron gun only a few millimeters in size but capable of producing MeV electrons will be designed, built and tested at high power. The group will explore the physics of electron field-emission and photo-emission in GV/m THz fields, THz gun electron beam dynamics, non-relativistic accelerating structures and electron beam generation on femtosecond timescales. This resulting increase in performance, compactness and efficiency will open new frontiers in accelerator science and its many applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview

High-gradient accelerators are of interest for a wide variety of applications such as ultrafast electron diffraction, free electron lasers, medical linear accelerators and future colliders. For these applications the cost, size and availability of accelerators is dominated by the achievable accelerating gradient. While high-gradient reduces the footprint of the accelerator it also reduces the efficiency of the overall system due to increased power requirements. This increase in required power and pulse energy can be mitigated by increasing the frequency of operation for an accelerator. Increased frequency reduces the energy required to achieve a desired accelerating gradient due to the reduced transverse size of the accelerating structure and reduced filling times. As an added benefit, increasing the operational RF frequency into the THz band allows for greatly increased accelerating gradients due to reduced complications with respect to breakdown and pulsed heating. In principle, GeV/m accelerating gradients could be achieved if the operational frequency is high enough.

With this motivation we have pursued the development of an ultra-compact high-gradient electron gun operating in the THz frequency range. This has involved testing the first structures THz accelerating structures at high gradient, designing an electron gun, simulating the beam dynamics, developing diagnostics suitable for a compact electron source and fabricating the first field emitting THz electron gun. The design of the fabricated electron gun predicts an energy gained by an electron in the gun is around one MeV. This technology is capable of being scaled to high energy with additional THz accelerating structures. The electron gun requires MW peak power pulses which will be provided using electron-beam driven MW-class THz sources.

Intellectual Merit

Several key achievements were accomplished in the course of this research. These include: (1) The completion of a full start to end simulation of the THz gun design and beam dynamics. These simulations demonstrated a high quality electron source can be produced by a THz gun. (2) The first successful fabrication and tuning of THz gun structure was realized by incorporating advanced fabrication techniques including additive approaches based electro forming and planting. (3) The realization of an experimental beamline for the THz electron gun that includes custom designed and build emittance and charge diagnostics, and an energy spectrometer.

Broader Impact

This program has supported the training of a PhD student and a postdoctoral researcher. The student gained exposure to the latest technology in high-power THz generation and advanced accelerators. The postdoctoral research developed new simulation tools for the modeling of electron beams in in accelerating structures including the back action of the electron beam on the rf performance of the accelerator.

THz-based particle accelerators driven hold the promise of having an immediate broad impact for the scientific community due to the widespread availability of THz sources. The first applications of this technology are being realized in ultrafast science. The many potential applications are of relevance to biologists, chemists and physicists investigating ultra-fast science through electron diffraction and to physicians developing new tools for medical therapy. By achieving accelerating gradients of a GeV/m we will also demonstrate the potential for using this technology in a future high energy accelerator for a collider or light source.
